sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome to one of the most important ideas in all of linear algebra. I’m Jihad Al Sayed, and today we’re unlocking the meaning of eigenvectors and eigenvalues — concepts that power everything from AI to physics.

sections.title: What Is an Eigenvector?
sections.content: An eigenvector of a matrix A is a vector that doesn’t change direction when A is applied — it only gets scaled. That scale factor is the eigenvalue.

sections.title: Geometric Interpretation
sections.content: Eigenvectors point in directions that are invariant under the transformation. They stretch or shrink but don’t rotate.

sections.title: Example Matrix
Applications of Eigenvectors
sections.content: Used in Google’s PageRank, PCA for dimensionality reduction, stability analysis in control systems, and quantum mechanics.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We explored what eigenvectors and eigenvalues are, how to compute them, and why they’re a core tool in every serious mathematical system or application.
